random

public static float random(float Seed)
Generates a random number. NOTE: To create a series of predictable random numbers, add the random number you generate each time to the Seed value before calling random() again.

Parameters:
Seed - A user-provided value used to calculate a predictable random number.
Returns:
A Number between 0 and 1.

getColor

public static int getColor(int Red,
                           int Green,
                           int Blue,
                           int Alpha)
Generate a Flash uint color from RGBA components.

Parameters:
Red - The red component, between 0 and 255.
Green - The green component, between 0 and 255.
Blue - The blue component, between 0 and 255.
Alpha - How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255.
Returns:
The color as a uint.

getColorHSB

public static int getColorHSB(int Hue,
                              int Saturation,
                              int Brightness,
                              int Alpha)
Generate a Flash uint color from HSB components.

Parameters:
Hue - A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel.
Saturation - A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant.
Brightness - A number between 0 and 1, indicating how bright the color should be. 0 is black, 1 is full bright.
Alpha - How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255.
Returns:
The color as a uint.

getRGBA

public static int[] getRGBA(int Color,
                            int[] Results)
Loads an array with the RGBA values of a Flash uint color. RGB values are stored 0-255. Alpha is stored as a floating point number between 0 and 1.

Parameters:
Color - The color you want to break into components.
Results - An optional parameter, allows you to use an array that already exists in memory to store the result.
Returns:
An Array object containing the Red, Green, Blue and Alpha values of the given color.

getHSB

public static int[] getHSB(int Color,
                           int[] Results)
Loads an array with the HSB values of a Flash uint color. Hue is a value between 0 and 360. Saturation, Brightness and Alpha are as floating point numbers between 0 and 1.

Parameters:
Color - The color you want to break into components.
Results - An optional parameter, allows you to use an array that already exists in memory to store the result.
Returns:
An Array object containing the Red, Green, Blue and Alpha values of the given color.

computeVelocity

public static float computeVelocity(float Velocity,
                                    float Acceleration,
                                    float Drag,
                                    float Max)
A tween-like function that takes a starting velocity and some other factors and returns an altered velocity.

Parameters:
Velocity - Any component of velocity (e.g. 20).
Acceleration - Rate at which the velocity is changing. 0 is default.
Drag - Really kind of a deceleration, this is how much the velocity changes if Acceleration is not set. 0 is default.
Max - An absolute value cap for the velocity. 10000 is default.
Returns:
The altered Velocity value.

setWorldBounds

public static void setWorldBounds(float X,
                                  float Y,
                                  int Width,
                                  int Height,
                                  int Divisions)
Call this function to specify a more efficient boundary for your game world. This boundary is used by overlap() and collide(), so it can't hurt to have it be the right size! Flixel will invent a size for you, but it's pretty huge - 256x the size of the screen, whatever that may be. Leave width and height empty if you want to just update the game world's position.

Parameters:
X - The X-coordinate of the left side of the game world.
Y - The Y-coordinate of the top of the game world.
Width - Desired width of the game world.
Height - Desired height of the game world.
Divisions - Pass a non-zero value to set quadTreeDivisions. Default value is 3.

setWorldBounds

public static void setWorldBounds(float X,
                                  float Y,
                                  int Width,
                                  int Height)

                                  int Width)

setWorldBounds

setWorldBounds

public static void setWorldBounds()

overlap

public static boolean overlap(FlxObject Object1,
                              FlxObject Object2,
                              FlxOverlapListener Callback)
Call this function to see if one FlxObject overlaps another. Can be called with one object and one group, or two groups, or two objects, whatever floats your boat! It will put everything into a quad tree and then check for overlaps. For maximum performance try bundling a lot of objects together using a FlxGroup (even bundling groups together!) NOTE: does NOT take objects' scrollfactor into account.

Parameters:
Object1 - The first object or group you want to check.
Object2 - The second object or group you want to check. If it is the same as the first, flixel knows to just do a comparison within that group.
Callback - A function with two FlxObject parameters - e.g. myOverlapFunction(Object1:FlxObject,Object2:FlxObject); If no function is provided, FlxQuadTree will call kill() on both objects.

overlap

public static boolean overlap(FlxObject Object1,
                              FlxObject Object2)

collide

public static boolean collide(FlxObject Object1,
                              FlxObject Object2)
Call this function to see if one FlxObject collides with another. Can be called with one object and one group, or two groups, or two objects, whatever floats your boat! It will put everything into a quad tree and then check for collisions. For maximum performance try bundling a lot of objects together using a FlxGroup (even bundling groups together!) NOTE: does NOT take objects' scrollfactor into account.

Parameters:
Object1 - The first object or group you want to check.
Object2 - The second object or group you want to check. If it is the same as the first, flixel knows to just do a comparison within that group.

solveXCollision

public static boolean solveXCollision(FlxObject Object1,
                                      FlxObject Object2)
This quad tree callback function can be used externally as well. Takes two objects and separates them along their X axis (if possible/reasonable).

Parameters:
Object1 - The first object or group you want to check.
Object2 - The second object or group you want to check.

solveYCollision

public static boolean solveYCollision(FlxObject Object1,
                                      FlxObject Object2)
This quad tree callback function can be used externally as well. Takes two objects and separates them along their Y axis (if possible/reasonable).

Parameters:
Object1 - The first object or group you want to check.
Object2 - The second object or group you want to check.
